output:
My pappy's pappy used to sing, he played those honky-tonks
It kept them off from starving once the cotton king was gone
It's a lot cash to the sharecropper to still have bills to pay
Though he'd try all night to harmonize and then sweat all through the day
I was back before this rock and roll, his electric guitar
Before Jimmy Rogers ever thought of yodeling a song
When he needed something new to sing to keep him coming through
Then as he'd work the fields to figure out a tune
You are my sunshine, my only sunshine
You make me happy when the skies are gray
You never know dear, how much I love you
Please don't take my sunshine away
One night when he was singing things the folks seemed like to hear
A stranger came to know it, town all polished and veneer
There was nothing about the man to think that he'd have something to steal
There was no one chasing after him and the cash he'd spend was real
Well he'd said he was a music star, played from coast to coast
And as a child I used to hear him on the grand old opera show
He had that Stetson hat, a walking cane, big old diamond ring
And in the evening he would hear my grandpa sing
You are my sunshine, my only sunshine
You make me happy when the skies are gray
You never know dear, how much I love you
Please don't take my sunshine away
Well ten years passed before the old man heard a radio
It was about then that he'd figured out the songs he wrote was gold
But a rich man ain't got time to hear what a poor man has to say
Oh he'd turn to gel as loud as he could until his dying day
I ain't sayin' I ain't never stole, but I'd never steal a song
Better take the words from someone's mouth, ain't nothing else but wrong
They can take away his right to sing, money he'd have made
But they'll never take what's written on his grave
You are my sunshine, my only sunshine
You make me happy when the skies are gray
You never know dear, how much I love you
Please don't take my sunshine away
Please don't take my sunshine away
